Congress debates aid bill
By BILL ABBOTT
A House-Senate Conference
Committee is currently debating
a controversial Senate federal aid
to higher education bill which
would radically change the
government's role on the nation's
campuses.
A guarentee of $1,400 toward
the education of every
undergraduate, unrestricted
grants to institutions totalling
$1.14 billion, and a $150 million
fund to rescue folding
institutions highlight this bill, the
most extensive of its kind in
history
The House and Senate each
passed its own version, which
differ on over 200 specifics.
There are indications the
conferees may spend another
month settling differences.
According to aides of Senator
Claiborne Pell (D-R.I.), original
sponsor of the Senate bill, the
most ominous threat to
successful compromise is a

strongly worded anti-busing rider
tacked onto the House version.
And, in an infrequent move, the
House instructed its conferees
not to compromise on the rider's
language.
Adding to the controversy on
what originally was a bill
referring strictly to higher
education, both houses passed
amendments issuing $1.5 billion
to local school districts for
desegregating primary and
secondary schools.
' Anything Can Happen
In the words of one Senate
Committee aide, "Anything can
happen now, maybe there won't
be any bill at all." In that case,
virtually all federal aid programs
to students and institutions could
come to a swift halt after their
June 30 expiration.
Senate and House provisions
both agree on direct funding to
college and university operating
budgets, which would be a first
in itself. But, the Senate measure

calls for $647 million in the first
year to be administered
according to the number of
students. receiving federal aid at
each school
The House version would
provide $1.14 billion, two-thirds
of which would be administered
by the total number of students
earning credits and one third by
the Senate guideline. House
advocates claim that their
program directs the aid -toward
the middle-income group, while
the Senate's centers on the
low-income strata.

carry advertising for either termpaper refercnce services
or abortion and family planning agencies which charge
a fee. The decision to discontinue the ads was made by
the News-Letter's Board of Control Wednesday night.
This decision is just an extension of existing editorial
policy, for nearly everything appearing in this newspaper is subject to editorial judgements. Stories are
assigned because we feel they are important to our
readers. Their content is inspected and edited before
they are printed. However, advertising content is
another story. An advertiser pays his money, and fills
his alloted space with just about whatever he wishes.
So, the Board of Control has no final authority to
make an advertiser change his copy; our only option is
to accept or to reject the advertisement. Thus, the
News-Letter's ad policy is determined not by the
content of printed ads, but by the types of ads they
are
Most advertising is a vital and important part of any
newspaper. Not only does it provide much of the
money necessary for publishing, but it informs readers
concerning what to buy,what they need and what to do
for entertainment: Ads for job interviews, for instance,
are a very important service. But ads for termpaper
reference services and for abortion and family planning
agencies which charge a fee are not included in what
the News-Letter believes to be this more important
category.
So, the Board of Control, made up of the paper's
editorial staff, decided by a majority vote to eliminate
these ads. The criteria used in the vote concerned our

aims for the News-Letter: to inform the Hopkins
community and to maintain our credibility, the lack of
which could threaten our effectiveness.

well as from outside the University, indicate that our
standing has been questioned as a result of these
advertisements. Involved in this standing is not just our
prestige, but our factual veracity, our editorial backing
and our ability to serve the community. When we
publish a story in the News-Letter, or take an editorial
stand, we do so because we feel that the community
should know about it. But to run ads which could be
construed as undercutting the value of this educational
service, is something we cannot allow to happen.
So, these ads are not going to run any longer: but
this does not mean that the News-Letter will not
continue to publish articles that might arouse controversy, or advertising that might seem offensive to some.
This newspaper's goal is to inform and serve the
University community. That is the way almost any
newspaper works, and that is the way we will.
But the advertising copy, a part of the paper that is
set apart from the rest of the paper am n that it is an
all-or-nothing proposition, is something more complicated. If certain kinds of advertising, such as these two
kinds, will jeopardize our objectives, then the entire
Hopkins community will lose. The News-Letter is the
most effective means of communication in the University, and if it loses some of its effectiveness because of
certain advertisements, then everyone would lose. And
the blame could be placed on us, the Board of Control.

This is the final issue of the News-Letter which will
carry advertising for either termpaper refercnce services
or abortion and family planning agencies which charge
a fee. The decision to discontinue the ads was made by
the News-Letter's Board of Control Wednesday night.
This decision is just an extension of existing editorial
policy, for nearly everything appearing in this newspaper is subject to editorial judgements. Stories are
assigned because we feel they are important to our
readers. Their content is inspected and edited before
they are printed. However, advertising content is
another story. An advertiser pays his money, and fills
his alloted space with just about whatever he wishes.
So, the Board of Control has no final authority to
make an advertiser change his copy; our only option is
to accept or to reject the advertisement. Thus, the
News-Letter's ad policy is determined not by the
content of printed ads, but by the types of ads they
are
Most advertising is a vital and important part of any
newspaper. Not only does it provide much of the
money necessary for publishing, but it informs readers
concerning what to buy,what they need and what to do
for entertainment: Ads for job interviews, for instance,
are a very important service. But ads for termpaper
reference services and for abortion and family planning
agencies which charge a fee are not included in what
the News-Letter believes to be this more important
category.
So, the Board of Control, made up of the paper's
editorial staff, decided by a majority vote to eliminate
these ads. The criteria used in the vote concerned our

aims for the News-Letter: to inform the Hopkins
community and to maintain our credibility, the lack of
which could threaten our effectiveness.
Reactions from all segments of the community, as
well as from outside the University, indicate that our
standing has been questioned as a result of these
advertisements. Involved in this standing is not just our
prestige, but our factual veracity, our editorial backing
and our ability to serve the community. When we
publish a story in the News-Letter, or take an editorial
stand, we do so because we feel that the community
should know about it. But to run ads which could be
construed as undercutting the value of this educational
service, is something we cannot allow to happen.
So, these ads are not going to run any longer: but
this does not mean that the News-Letter will not
continue to publish articles that might arouse controversy, or advertising that might seem offensive to some.
This newspaper's goal is to inform and serve the
University community. That is the way almost any
newspaper works, and that is the way we will.
But the advertising copy, a part of the paper that is
set apart from the rest of the paper am n that it is an
all-or-nothing proposition, is something more complicated. If certain kinds of advertising, such as these two
kinds, will jeopardize our objectives, then the entire
Hopkins community will lose. The News-Letter is the
most effective means of communication in the University, and if it loses some of its effectiveness because of
certain advertisements, then everyone would lose. And
the blame could be placed on us, the Board of Control.
We just don't want that to happen.
